abstract.p: Editorial lauds New Jersey Nets basketball team for advancing to NBA's Eastern Conference finals for first time in its history (S)

block.p: The New Jersey Nets basketball team started this season playing in a half-empty arena in the Meadowlands before fans who expected so little that they seemed hesitant to even cheer. The arena began to fill up as the Nets surged through the season. It was jam-packed and rocking this week when the team, in the Eastern Conference finals for the first time in its history, bulled its way past the Boston Celtics to take the first game of this series. The process that took the Nets from doormat to juggernaut offers lessons for the venerable but ailing New York Knicks, who failed to make the playoffs after a dismal season that sent basketball fans streaming across the Hudson River into New Jersey.

While the Knicks were standing pat with a team of aging stars, the Nets made strong draft choices and courageous trades. When the team seemed too soft, it acquired the roughhouse power forward Kenyon Martin, whose mental toughness was just what the doctor ordered. When the Nets seemed to be standing around watching each other on the court, the front office traded a star player for Jason Kidd, whose passing skills have forced this once-wooden team to actually get out and run. Also crucial was Byron Scott, whose performance made him a contender for the coach of the year award.
